values.description:
This was fixed on pull request #444 for Citadel. Backporting it now to Blueprint.

With this fix, you can drop several lights into the scene without a crash. Try dragging the sun for example: https://app.ignitionrobotics.org/openrobotics/fuel/models/Sun
values.title: Backport fix to insert multiple lights with same name

summary.html:
This was fixed on pull request #444 for Citadel. Backporting it now to Blueprint.

values.description:
Some suggestions:

* Remove `ServerConfig::LogRecordOverwrite` because it was not being used. It would be misleading to keep it there, because it implies that the server can be setup to handle no overwrite, when in fact, this needs to be handled before the server is instantiated and the final path be passed to the server config. I realized this while writing some tests to check that a new folder is created for no overwrite.

* Removed the checks for `ignLogDirectory` on the `LogOverwrite` test, because that path is set in the beginning of the test and is not expected to change.

* Added an `entryCount` function and check when new log directories with `(1)` are created, or not.

* Remove `removeFile`s from the beginning of each overwrite test case, so we can check that the file is overwritten, as opposed to a new file written.

* Check that `server_console.log` ends up together with `state.log`

* Add test that doesn't overwrite

* Removed unused test world
values.title: Updates to log overwrite tests -> pull request #497

summary.raw:
Some suggestions:

* Remove `ServerConfig::LogRecordOverwrite` because it was not being used. It would be misleading to keep it there, because it implies that the server can be setup to handle no overwrite, when in fact, this needs to be handled before the server is instantiated and the final path be passed to the server config. I realized this while writing some tests to check that a new folder is created for no overwrite.

* Removed the checks for `ignLogDirectory` on the `LogOverwrite` test, because that path is set in the beginning of the test and is not expected to change.

* Added an `entryCount` function and check when new log directories with `(1)` are created, or not.

* Remove `removeFile`s from the beginning of each overwrite test case, so we can check that the file is overwritten, as opposed to a new file written.

* Check that `server_console.log` ends up together with `state.log`

* Add test that doesn't overwrite

* Removed unused test world
summary.html:
Some suggestions:

  • Remove ServerConfig::LogRecordOverwrite because it was not being used. It would be misleading to keep it there, because it implies that the server can be setup to handle no overwrite, when in fact, this needs to be handled before the server is instantiated and the final path be passed to the server config. I realized this while writing some tests to check that a new folder is created for no overwrite.

  • Removed the checks for ignLogDirectory on the LogOverwrite test, because that path is set in the beginning of the test and is not expected to change.

  • Added an entryCount function and check when new log directories with (1) are created, or not.

  • Remove removeFiles from the beginning of each overwrite test case, so we can check that the file is overwritten, as opposed to a new file written.

  • Check that server_console.log ends up together with state.log

  • Add test that doesn't overwrite

  • Removed unused test world

values.description:
This is marked WIP because it needs new releases of SDF9 and ign-common3. We can't make those until after the Urban Circuit. 

This is a port of [Gazebo classic's buoyancy plugin](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/default/plugins/BuoyancyPlugin.hh). 

The behavior of this Buoyancy plugin matches that of Gazebo classic. The primary difference is that this new plugin can calculate the volume of meshes. The old plugin offered some more customization via plugin SDF elements. I left those out for now since I didn't have a good use case.

I could use some eyes on the math in `Buoyancy.cc`.
values.title: Buoyancy

summary.raw:
This is marked WIP because it needs new releases of SDF9 and ign-common3. We can't make those until after the Urban Circuit. 

This is a port of [Gazebo classic's buoyancy plugin](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/default/plugins/BuoyancyPlugin.hh). 

The behavior of this Buoyancy plugin matches that of Gazebo classic. The primary difference is that this new plugin can calculate the volume of meshes. The old plugin offered some more customization via plugin SDF elements. I left those out for now since I didn't have a good use case.

I could use some eyes on the math in `Buoyancy.cc`.
summary.html:
This is marked WIP because it needs new releases of SDF9 and ign-common3. We can't make those until after the Urban Circuit.

This is a port of Gazebo classic's buoyancy plugin.

The behavior of this Buoyancy plugin matches that of Gazebo classic. The primary difference is that this new plugin can calculate the volume of meshes. The old plugin offered some more customization via plugin SDF elements. I left those out for now since I didn't have a good use case.

I could use some eyes on the math in Buoyancy.cc.

values.description:
By adding `<grid>` and `<plugin filename="GridConfig" ...>` to a file, grid GUI is loaded as plugin into ignition. An example sdf file is given below `grid.sdf`. The GUI allows user to modify cell count, cell length, pose and color. Currently, the GUI only works from sdf plugin, and not from the dropdown menu, due to possible conflict of default rendering engine `ogre` and dropdown menu engine `ogre2`

A relevant qml template used in the GUI is also added to `ign-gui` in this PR [#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/pull-requests/239](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gui/pull-requests/239). It needs to be merged before this PR to prevent breaking.

A screen shot of the GUI

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1163921760-grid-gui.gif)
‌
values.title: Add GUI to configure grid

values.description: for simulation thermal cameras, we need a way for users to specify the temperature of the environment. This PR adds support for reading the temperature data from an `<atmosphere>` sdf element in the world. The temperature data will be passed to the thermal camera sensor in [part 3](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/514).
values.title: Thermal camera Part 1: Ambient temperature

summary.raw: for simulation thermal cameras, we need a way for users to specify the temperature of the environment. This PR adds support for reading the temperature data from an `<atmosphere>` sdf element in the world. The temperature data will be passed to the thermal camera sensor in [part 3](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/514).
summary.html: for simulation thermal cameras, we need a way for users to specify the temperature of the environment. This PR adds support for reading the temperature data from an <atmosphere> sdf element in the world. The temperature data will be passed to the thermal camera sensor in part 3.

values.description:
depends on pull request #512

This PR adds support for loading visual plugins \(or systems attached to a visual\), which is used for specifying the temperature of objects \(i.e. heat source\) for thermal camera simulation.

Also added a temperature component for passing data from the visual plugin to the rendering system.

Test by running the `thermal_camera.sdf` world and you should these msgs in the console:

```
[Msg] Thermal system: setting box_visual's temperature to 200
[Msg] Thermal system: setting sphere_visual's temperature to 600
[Msg] Thermal system: setting cylinder_visual's temperature to 400
```

‌
values.title: Thermal camera Part 2: heat source

This PR adds support for loading visual plugins \(or systems attached to a visual\), which is used for specifying the temperature of objects \(i.e. heat source\) for thermal camera simulation.

depends on pull request #512 and pull request #513

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/3153351459-thermal_camera_gazebo.png)
‌

values.description:
Highlight selected entities on the world and the menu.

Some examples using Ogre 1 and 2:

![highlight_1.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/2725716442-highlight_1.gif)
![highlight_2.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/2872878114-highlight_2.gif)
![highlight_3.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1850624746-highlight_3.gif)

This adds the `GuiEvents.hh` header like pull request #493.

Unfortunately, the Gazebo-classic-style bounding box can't be added to Blueprint or Citadel, because it would break Ignition Rendering's ABI. So this method using the emissive light is just a filler to provide the user some feedback on the older versions. I'm open to other non-ABI-breaking suggestions.
values.title: Highlight selected entities

Unfortunately, the Gazebo-classic-style bounding box can't be added to Blueprint or Citadel, because it would break Ignition Rendering's ABI. So this method using the emissive light is just a filler to provide the user some feedback on the older versions. I'm open to other non-ABI-breaking suggestions.

values.description: There is no guarantee that the texture id is also ways the same since ign-rendering destroys and recreates textures and other resources when needed, e.g. when size changes or number of shadow-casting lights change. I ran into a black gui window a few times in subt caused by invalid texture ids when the robot moves in and out of levels \(which caused number of lights to change\).
values.title: Always use the latest render texture id in scene3d

summary.raw: There is no guarantee that the texture id is also ways the same since ign-rendering destroys and recreates textures and other resources when needed, e.g. when size changes or number of shadow-casting lights change. I ran into a black gui window a few times in subt caused by invalid texture ids when the robot moves in and out of levels \(which caused number of lights to change\).
summary.html: There is no guarantee that the texture id is also ways the same since ign-rendering destroys and recreates textures and other resources when needed, e.g. when size changes or number of shadow-casting lights change. I ran into a black gui window a few times in subt caused by invalid texture ids when the robot moves in and out of levels (which caused number of lights to change).

values.description: Currently, levels to be unloaded are checked and printed redundantly. This is caused by an incorrect usage of `std::unique` which needs a vector to be sorted for it to remove redundant elements.
values.title: Remove redundent messages when levels get unloaded

values.description:
issue #46

The cause of the bug when jumping back in time was that the log playback system is setting the ECM to a state based on a ‘changed’ state \(state describing an incremental difference between the current and previous iteration\) and not an absolute state.  

The workaround is to rewind to the beginning and play until the ‘seek’ time. The proper fix should be to periodically store the absolute state of the ECS when recording. i.e. key frames.
values.title: Fix seeking back in time in log playback

summary.raw:
issue #46

The cause of the bug when jumping back in time was that the log playback system is setting the ECM to a state based on a ‘changed’ state \(state describing an incremental difference between the current and previous iteration\) and not an absolute state.  

The workaround is to rewind to the beginning and play until the ‘seek’ time. The proper fix should be to periodically store the absolute state of the ECS when recording. i.e. key frames.
summary.html:
issue #46

The cause of the bug when jumping back in time was that the log playback system is setting the ECM to a state based on a ‘changed’ state (state describing an incremental difference between the current and previous iteration) and not an absolute state.

The workaround is to rewind to the beginning and play until the ‘seek’ time. The proper fix should be to periodically store the absolute state of the ECS when recording. i.e. key frames.

values.description:
Combines the functionality from `add_keybindings` (#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/486) and `select_entities` (#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-gazebo/pull-requests/515).  These two previously mentioned PRs definitely need to be merged before this one is.

This PR allows the user to select entities as well as hold Ctrl while selecting entities to select more than one.  This behavior also transfers to the TransformControl plugin. It's nearly done but has some very specific cases and intricacies.


TODO: 
- select only most recently clicked entity when multiple entities are selected and the transform controller is not in a none state
- Find a way to disable the selection of more entities via the tree view when transform control is already on on
values.title: [WIP] Multiple Select Entities

values.description:
Plugin that lists all components attached to an entity.

* All components are listed, even custom components from downstream users. 
* Some known components have their contents displayed, such as pose, vector, string, boolean...
* Component data is updated at the same rate as `Scene3d`'s
* The component type name and ID are displayed by hovering over the component name. This is meant to help plugin writers debug their simulations.
* The first version of the plugin is meant to be read-only, but some elements like `SpinBox` don't support being disabled. I may change them to plain text before merging this PR. A subsequent PR will add write functionality.
* Components that mark an entity's type, like `Model` or `Light`, are displayed up top with an accompanying icon. They don't show on the list below right now, but I wonder if it would be clearer for users if they did.

![CI_world.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/2669212787-CI_world.gif)

![CI_model.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/3177696299-CI_model.gif)

![CI_light.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/1995952740-CI_light.gif)

![CI_joint.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/3714013003-CI_joint.gif)

## TODO

* ~~Support custom units on `Vector3d.qml` so gravity and magnetic field display correctly~~
* ~~Add a `+` to the collapsible components?~~
* ~~Gather feedback on usability~~
* ~~I added some initial support for displaying the serialized data of unknown components, which should help downstream developers debugging their components. But many of them, like the ones coming from messages, look like garbage. This could confuse users. Maybe hide raw data behind a setting?~~ Removed raw data for now
* ~~Entity selection still needs to be sorted out, see pull request #515 and pull request #524~~
* Create custom widgets for more known types (material, geometry, inertial...) - coming up in follow up PRs
values.title: Component inspector

summary.raw:
Plugin that lists all components attached to an entity.

* All components are listed, even custom components from downstream users. 
* Some known components have their contents displayed, such as pose, vector, string, boolean...
* Component data is updated at the same rate as `Scene3d`'s
* The component type name and ID are displayed by hovering over the component name. This is meant to help plugin writers debug their simulations.
* The first version of the plugin is meant to be read-only, but some elements like `SpinBox` don't support being disabled. I may change them to plain text before merging this PR. A subsequent PR will add write functionality.
* Components that mark an entity's type, like `Model` or `Light`, are displayed up top with an accompanying icon. They don't show on the list below right now, but I wonder if it would be clearer for users if they did.

![CI_world.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/2669212787-CI_world.gif)

![CI_model.gif](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/3177696299-CI_model.gif)

## TODO

* ~~Support custom units on `Vector3d.qml` so gravity and magnetic field display correctly~~
* ~~Add a `+` to the collapsible components?~~
* ~~Gather feedback on usability~~
* ~~I added some initial support for displaying the serialized data of unknown components, which should help downstream developers debugging their components. But many of them, like the ones coming from messages, look like garbage. This could confuse users. Maybe hide raw data behind a setting?~~ Removed raw data for now
* ~~Entity selection still needs to be sorted out, see pull request #515 and pull request #524~~
* Create custom widgets for more known types (material, geometry, inertial...) - coming up in follow up PRs
summary.html:
Plugin that lists all components attached to an entity.

  • All components are listed, even custom components from downstream users.
  • Some known components have their contents displayed, such as pose, vector, string, boolean...
  • Component data is updated at the same rate as Scene3d's
  • The component type name and ID are displayed by hovering over the component name. This is meant to help plugin writers debug their simulations.
  • The first version of the plugin is meant to be read-only, but some elements like SpinBox don't support being disabled. I may change them to plain text before merging this PR. A subsequent PR will add write functionality.
  • Components that mark an entity's type, like Model or Light, are displayed up top with an accompanying icon. They don't show on the list below right now, but I wonder if it would be clearer for users if they did.

TODO

  • Support custom units on Vector3d.qml so gravity and magnetic field display correctly
  • Add a + to the collapsible components?
  • Gather feedback on usability
  • I added some initial support for displaying the serialized data of unknown components, which should help downstream developers debugging their components. But many of them, like the ones coming from messages, look like garbage. This could confuse users. Maybe hide raw data behind a setting? Removed raw data for now
  • Entity selection still needs to be sorted out, see pull request #515 and pull request #524
  • Create custom widgets for more known types (material, geometry, inertial...) - coming up in follow up PRs

values.description: I detected a bug which occurs when one is translating with the use of the Shift key for world frame and lets go while continuing to drag with the mouse; in this case, the entity will jump back to its starting point.  This PR fixes this issue by updating the position of the entity upon a shift press and release.
values.title: Fix shift translation bug

summary.raw: I detected a bug which occurs when one is translating with the use of the Shift key for world frame and lets go while continuing to drag with the mouse; in this case, the entity will jump back to its starting point.  This PR fixes this issue by updating the position of the entity upon a shift press and release.
summary.html: I detected a bug which occurs when one is translating with the use of the Shift key for world frame and lets go while continuing to drag with the mouse; in this case, the entity will jump back to its starting point. This PR fixes this issue by updating the position of the entity upon a shift press and release.

values.description:
Needs:

* ~~#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-fuel-tools/pull-requests/123/~~ released
* ~~#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/226/~~ releases

Until now, Fuel URLs could be used only within `<include>` tags. This PR enables their use within any tag that supports URIs, such as `<uri>` and `<filename>`.

The main things needed for this to happen are:

* `common::MeshManager` needs to call a Fuel callback to fetch meshes. The `ign-common` PR allows that.
* `fuel_tools::fetchResource` needs to support mesh files. The `ign-fuel-tools` PR adds that.

This was motivated by the need to more easily embed actors within a world. Without this PR, it's quite inconvenient to need to hardcode the actor's trajectory within the actor's SDF file.
values.title: Support <uri>s from Fuel

summary.raw:
Needs:

* ~~#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-fuel-tools/pull-requests/123/~~ released
* ~~#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/226/~~ releases

Until now, Fuel URLs could be used only within `<include>` tags. This PR enables their use within any tag that supports URIs, such as `<uri>` and `<filename>`.

The main things needed for this to happen are:

* `common::MeshManager` needs to call a Fuel callback to fetch meshes. The `ign-common` PR allows that.
* `fuel_tools::fetchResource` needs to support mesh files. The `ign-fuel-tools` PR adds that.

This was motivated by the need to more easily embed actors within a world. Without this PR, it's quite inconvenient to need to hardcode the actor's trajectory within the actor's SDF file.
summary.html:
Needs:

  • #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-fuel-tools/pull-requests/123/ released
  • #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/226/ releases

Until now, Fuel URLs could be used only within <include> tags. This PR enables their use within any tag that supports URIs, such as <uri> and <filename>.

The main things needed for this to happen are:

  • common::MeshManager needs to call a Fuel callback to fetch meshes. The ign-common PR allows that.
  • fuel_tools::fetchResource needs to support mesh files. The ign-fuel-tools PR adds that.

This was motivated by the need to more easily embed actors within a world. Without this PR, it's quite inconvenient to need to hardcode the actor's trajectory within the actor's SDF file.

values.description:
The `<actor><pose>` tag was being ignored. In fact, it is also essentially ignored on Gazebo-classic.

This PR makes it so all poses within the actor's trajectory are calculated with respect to the actor's top-level pose. The actor's root pose initially comes from the SDF, and can be updated by other plugins at runtime (I can add a demo for this).

This is a breaking change for users who have been setting the `<pose>` value to an arbitrary value. It actually breaks @{557058:ad32c2b0-bebb-403e-b385-c3c1f7aa1d09} 's [actor](https://app.ignitionrobotics.org/Mingfei/fuel/models/actor) which we've been using on the demo. That actor has a pose of 1 in Z, so now the actor performs its trajectory while floating 1 meter above ground.

Given the side-effect above, I'd be ok retargetting this change to Dome.
values.title: Support <actor><pose>

summary.raw:
The `<actor><pose>` tag was being ignored. In fact, it is also essentially ignored on Gazebo-classic.

This PR makes it so all poses within the actor's trajectory are calculated with respect to the actor's top-level pose. The actor's root pose initially comes from the SDF, and can be updated by other plugins at runtime (I can add a demo for this).

This is a breaking change for users who have been setting the `<pose>` value to an arbitrary value. It actually breaks @{557058:ad32c2b0-bebb-403e-b385-c3c1f7aa1d09} 's [actor](https://app.ignitionrobotics.org/Mingfei/fuel/models/actor) which we've been using on the demo. That actor has a pose of 1 in Z, so now the actor performs its trajectory while floating 1 meter above ground.

Given the side-effect above, I'd be ok retargetting this change to Dome.
summary.html:
The <actor><pose> tag was being ignored. In fact, it is also essentially ignored on Gazebo-classic.

This PR makes it so all poses within the actor's trajectory are calculated with respect to the actor's top-level pose. The actor's root pose initially comes from the SDF, and can be updated by other plugins at runtime (I can add a demo for this).

This is a breaking change for users who have been setting the <pose> value to an arbitrary value. It actually breaks @mingfei sun 's actor which we've been using on the demo. That actor has a pose of 1 in Z, so now the actor performs its trajectory while floating 1 meter above ground.

Given the side-effect above, I'd be ok retargetting this change to Dome.

values.description:
This PR adds usage of interpolate\_x SDF parameter for actor animations.  
Previously, the model pose was computed in a bit of a hacky way depending on a hardcoded distance threshold of 0.1, less than threshold resulted in normal animation playback, greater than threshold automatically switched to X interpolated animation, ignoring the sdf tag.

This PR removes the hack and uses the sdf tag instead to determine the animation playback speed, in a way similar to how it is [currently done in gazebo](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/c1537db2c8550db2566a634fcee382a7ab6d7fbe/gazebo/physics/Actor.cc#lines-778).

Targeting default because it might break existing behavior and it requires an ABI \(I believe\) breaking change in ign-common that will need to target default as well.

I’m not particularly happy with the “-1” hack, but it’s the only way I could get this to work in this example.

To test I used the actor.sdf example world, changing the model.sdf for the actor to the following:

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.6">
    <actor name="actor_test">
        <pose>0 0 1.0 0 0 0</pose>
        <skin>
            <filename>file:///home/luca/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/Mingfei/models/actor/1//meshes/walk.dae</filename>
            <scale>1.0</scale>
        </skin>
        <animation name="walk_ni">
            <filename>file:///home/luca/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/Mingfei/models/actor/1//meshes/walk.dae</filename>
            <scale>1.0</scale>
            <interpolate_x>false</interpolate_x>
        </animation><animation name="walk">
            <filename>file:///home/luca/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/Mingfei/models/actor/1//meshes/walk.dae</filename>
            <scale>1.0</scale>
            <interpolate_x>true</interpolate_x>
        </animation>
        <script>
            <loop>true</loop>
            <delay_start>1.0</delay_start>
            <auto_start>true</auto_start>
            <trajectory id="4" type="walk_ni">
                <waypoint>
                    <time>0</time>
                    <pose>0 0 1.0 0 0 1.57</pose>
                </waypoint>
                <waypoint>
                    <time>4</time>
                    <pose>0 4 1.0 0 0 1.57</pose>
                </waypoint>
            </trajectory>
            <trajectory id="5" type="walk">
                <waypoint>
                    <time>0</time>
                    <pose>0 4 1.0 0 0 -1.57</pose>
                </waypoint>
                <waypoint>
                    <time>4</time>
                    <pose>0 0 1.0 0 0 -1.57</pose>
                </waypoint>
            </trajectory>
        </script>
    </actor>
</sdf>
```

Result is the following, before the PRs \(interpolate\_x tag is ignored\):

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/3559567351-actor_before_pr.gif)
And after \(the tag is used\):

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/3624619904-actor_post_pr.gif)
Depends on ign-common PR [#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/232](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/232)
values.title: Using interpolate_x sdf value for animation playback speed

summary.raw:
This PR adds usage of interpolate\_x SDF parameter for actor animations.  
Previously, the model pose was computed in a bit of a hacky way depending on a hardcoded distance threshold of 0.1, less than threshold resulted in normal animation playback, greater than threshold automatically switched to X interpolated animation, ignoring the sdf tag.

This PR removes the hack and uses the sdf tag instead to determine the animation playback speed, in a way similar to how it is [currently done in gazebo](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/gazebo/src/c1537db2c8550db2566a634fcee382a7ab6d7fbe/gazebo/physics/Actor.cc#lines-778).

Targeting default because it might break existing behavior and it requires an ABI \(I believe\) breaking change in ign-common that will need to target default as well.

I’m not particularly happy with the “-1” hack, but it’s the only way I could get this to work in this example.

To test I used the actor.sdf example world, changing the model.sdf for the actor to the following:

```xml
<?xml version="1.0" ?>
<sdf version="1.6">
    <actor name="actor_test">
        <pose>0 0 1.0 0 0 0</pose>
        <skin>
            <filename>file:///home/luca/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/Mingfei/models/actor/1//meshes/walk.dae</filename>
            <scale>1.0</scale>
        </skin>
        <animation name="walk_ni">
            <filename>file:///home/luca/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/Mingfei/models/actor/1//meshes/walk.dae</filename>
            <scale>1.0</scale>
            <interpolate_x>false</interpolate_x>
        </animation><animation name="walk">
            <filename>file:///home/luca/.ignition/fuel/fuel.ignitionrobotics.org/Mingfei/models/actor/1//meshes/walk.dae</filename>
            <scale>1.0</scale>
            <interpolate_x>true</interpolate_x>
        </animation>
        <script>
            <loop>true</loop>
            <delay_start>1.0</delay_start>
            <auto_start>true</auto_start>
            <trajectory id="4" type="walk_ni">
                <waypoint>
                    <time>0</time>
                    <pose>0 0 1.0 0 0 1.57</pose>
                </waypoint>
                <waypoint>
                    <time>4</time>
                    <pose>0 4 1.0 0 0 1.57</pose>
                </waypoint>
            </trajectory>
            <trajectory id="5" type="walk">
                <waypoint>
                    <time>0</time>
                    <pose>0 4 1.0 0 0 -1.57</pose>
                </waypoint>
                <waypoint>
                    <time>4</time>
                    <pose>0 0 1.0 0 0 -1.57</pose>
                </waypoint>
            </trajectory>
        </script>
    </actor>
</sdf>
```

Result is the following, before the PRs \(interpolate\_x tag is ignored\):

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/3559567351-actor_before_pr.gif)
And after \(the tag is used\):

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/3624619904-actor_post_pr.gif)
Depends on ign-common PR [#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/232](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-common/pull-requests/232)
summary.html:
This PR adds usage of interpolate_x SDF parameter for actor animations.
Previously, the model pose was computed in a bit of a hacky way depending on a hardcoded distance threshold of 0.1, less than threshold resulted in normal animation playback, greater than threshold automatically switched to X interpolated animation, ignoring the sdf tag.

This PR removes the hack and uses the sdf tag instead to determine the animation playback speed, in a way similar to how it is currently done in gazebo.

Targeting default because it might break existing behavior and it requires an ABI (I believe) breaking change in ign-common that will need to target default as well.

I’m not particularly happy with the “-1” hack, but it’s the only way I could get this to work in this example.

To test I used the actor.sdf example world, changing the model.sdf for the actor to the following:

</sdf>

values.description:
This pull request allows the `SimulationRunner` to fall back to a default plugin configuration when one is not specified either via the `ServerConfig` \(via `ign-launch`\) or in the `.sdf` file.

If plugins aren’t found, it will search, in order:

1. A file located at  environment variable `IGN_GAZEBO_DEFAULT_SYSTEMS`
2. A file located at `~/.ignition/gazebo/systems.config`
3. A file located at `${IGN_DATA_INSTALL_DIR}/systems/systems.config`

The format of the file is similar to how plugins are specified in `ign-launch`

One additional update is that a wildcard entity name is now supported for the world entity type, which will allow the plugin to be attached to any world entity without knowing the name in advance.
values.title: Fallback to default plugin configuration

summary.raw:
This pull request allows the `SimulationRunner` to fall back to a default plugin configuration when one is not specified either via the `ServerConfig` \(via `ign-launch`\) or in the `.sdf` file.

If plugins aren’t found, it will search, in order:

1. A file located at  environment variable `IGN_GAZEBO_DEFAULT_SYSTEMS`
2. A file located at `~/.ignition/gazebo/systems.config`
3. A file located at `${IGN_DATA_INSTALL_DIR}/systems/systems.config`

The format of the file is similar to how plugins are specified in `ign-launch`

One additional update is that a wildcard entity name is now supported for the world entity type, which will allow the plugin to be attached to any world entity without knowing the name in advance.
summary.html:
This pull request allows the SimulationRunner to fall back to a default plugin configuration when one is not specified either via the ServerConfig (via ign-launch) or in the .sdf file.

If plugins aren’t found, it will search, in order:

  1. A file located at environment variable IGN_GAZEBO_DEFAULT_SYSTEMS
  2. A file located at ~/.ignition/gazebo/systems.config
  3. A file located at ${IGN_DATA_INSTALL_DIR}/systems/systems.config

The format of the file is similar to how plugins are specified in ign-launch

One additional update is that a wildcard entity name is now supported for the world entity type, which will allow the plugin to be attached to any world entity without knowing the name in advance.

values.description:
It should be possible to compile Ignition Gazebo even if DART is not installed. We should also let users load their own physics engines.

This PR removes the hard dependency on DART and lets users choose other physics engines at runtime. Ignition Gazebo will still try to load DART by default, but will fail to load physics if DART's Ignition Physics plugin can't be found. An error is printed and simulation keeps running without physics.

See tutorial below for usage.

This can be tested using the hello world engine from [this pull request](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/119/add-simple-example-of-physics-plugin-and/diff) and [this world](https://gist.github.com/chapulina/a3e13b25e5f325ea972e16b9c8ecb51a):

```
cd ign-physics/examples/hello_world
mkdir build
cd build
cmake ..
make
cd ..
IGN_GAZEBO_PHYSICS_ENGINE_PATH=`pwd`/build ign gazebo -v 1 build/rolling_box.sdf
```

You should see the message:

`[Err] [Physics.cc:308] Engine [mock::HelloWorldPlugin] is missing required features and can't be loaded.`

Another option is to use the command line, for example:

`IGN_GAZEBO_PHYSICS_ENGINE_PATH=`pwd`/build ign gazebo -v 1 --physics-engine HelloWorldPlugin shapes.sdf`

If you try without the env var, you'll see:

`[Err] [Physics.cc:287] Failed to find plugin [libHelloWorldPlugin.so]. Have you checked the IGN_GAZEBO_PHYSICS_ENGINE_PATH environment variable?`

:warning: **Out of scope:**

* automatically choosing an appropriate physics engine based on the features needed by the simulation
* supporting engines with a different set of features - see pull request #573 for that

---

## ~~TODO~~ DONE

~~I'd like to apply the same idea of pull request #222 to Ignition Physics so that the engine plugins are also installed to unvesioned files and users can use that on the SDF.~~ This pull request now depends on [this ign-physics PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/121/) .
values.title: Find custom physics engines

summary.raw:
It should be possible to compile Ignition Gazebo even if DART is not installed. We should also let users load their own physics engines.

This PR removes the hard dependency on DART and lets users choose other physics engines at runtime. Ignition Gazebo will still try to load DART by default, but will fail to load physics if DART's Ignition Physics plugin can't be found. An error is printed and simulation keeps running without physics.

See tutorial below for usage.

This can be tested using the hello world engine from [this pull request](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/119/add-simple-example-of-physics-plugin-and/diff) and [this world](https://gist.github.com/chapulina/a3e13b25e5f325ea972e16b9c8ecb51a):

```
cd ign-physics/examples/hello_world
mkdir build
cd build
cmake ..
make
cd ..
IGN_GAZEBO_PHYSICS_ENGINE_PATH=`pwd`/build ign gazebo -v 1 build/rolling_box.sdf
```

You should see the message:

`[Err] [Physics.cc:308] Engine [mock::HelloWorldPlugin] is missing required features and can't be loaded.`

Another option is to use the command line, for example:

`IGN_GAZEBO_PHYSICS_ENGINE_PATH=`pwd`/build ign gazebo -v 1 --physics-engine HelloWorldPlugin shapes.sdf`

If you try without the env var, you'll see:

`[Err] [Physics.cc:287] Failed to find plugin [libHelloWorldPlugin.so]. Have you checked the IGN_GAZEBO_PHYSICS_ENGINE_PATH environment variable?`

:warning: **Out of scope:**

* automatically choosing an appropriate physics engine based on the features needed by the simulation
* supporting engines with a different set of features - see pull request #573 for that

---

## ~~TODO~~ DONE

~~I'd like to apply the same idea of pull request #222 to Ignition Physics so that the engine plugins are also installed to unvesioned files and users can use that on the SDF.~~ This pull request now depends on [this ign-physics PR](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/121/) .
summary.html:
It should be possible to compile Ignition Gazebo even if DART is not installed. We should also let users load their own physics engines.

This PR removes the hard dependency on DART and lets users choose other physics engines at runtime. Ignition Gazebo will still try to load DART by default, but will fail to load physics if DART's Ignition Physics plugin can't be found. An error is printed and simulation keeps running without physics.

See tutorial below for usage.

This can be tested using the hello world engine from this pull request and this world:

cd ign-physics/examples/hello_world
mkdir build
cd build
cmake ..
make
cd ..
IGN_GAZEBO_PHYSICS_ENGINE_PATH=`pwd`/build ign gazebo -v 1 build/rolling_box.sdf

You should see the message:

[Err] [Physics.cc:308] Engine [mock::HelloWorldPlugin] is missing required features and can't be loaded.

Another option is to use the command line, for example:

IGN_GAZEBO_PHYSICS_ENGINE_PATH=pwd/build ign gazebo -v 1 --physics-engine HelloWorldPlugin shapes.sdf

If you try without the env var, you'll see:

[Err] [Physics.cc:287] Failed to find plugin [libHelloWorldPlugin.so]. Have you checked the IGN_GAZEBO_PHYSICS_ENGINE_PATH environment variable?

Out of scope:

  • automatically choosing an appropriate physics engine based on the features needed by the simulation
  • supporting engines with a different set of features - see pull request #573 for that

TODO DONE

I'd like to apply the same idea of pull request #222 to Ignition Physics so that the engine plugins are also installed to unvesioned files and users can use that on the SDF. This pull request now depends on this ign-physics PR .

values.description:
Retarget pull request #533 to Dome.

Needs [this](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/669/include-overrides-for-actor-and-light/diff) SDFormat PR.

* Add support for `<actor><plugin>`
* Use `<actor><pose>` as the origin of the trajectory
* Demo plugin that updates the trajectory origin at runtime

This method of setting the pose is not the most useful. I'll follow up with another PR that overrides the trajectory in the SDF.
values.title: [Dome] Support <actor><pose> and <actor><plugin>

This method of setting the pose is not the most useful. I'll follow up with another PR that overrides the trajectory in the SDF.

  • Add support for <actor><plugin>
  • Use <actor><pose> as the origin of the trajectory
  • Demo plugin that updates the trajectory origin at runtime

This method of setting the pose is not the most useful. I'll follow up with another PR that overrides the trajectory in the SDF.

values.description:
This PR adds a service for generating SDFormat strings/files for worlds. There are multiple options for generating the SDFormat. 

1. Expand and inline included models
2. Use the Fuel version in the URI generated for the model
3. Use absolute or relative paths for resources such as meshes
4. Copy model resources, such as meshes, and create a self contained model. 

Of these options, only the first two are currently implemented in this PR.

Limitations:

- Only models in the ECM are generated. This means a world that uses levels won't be saved correctly
- The pose of models does not get updated properly if changes are made using the GUI transform tool while simulation is paused and the SDF generation service is called. It looks like the Pose component is not updated while simulation is paused. I think fixing that is beyond the scope of this PR.

Assumptions:

- In order to get the version number of Fuel URIs, I assume that the directory containing the model has a name that specifies the version.

TODO:

  - ~~Tie this into the GUI and save to file~~
 
Required:

- [ign-msgs PR #174](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/174/)


# Try It

Run:

```ign gazebo -v 4 -r empty.sdf```

Insert models using the `/world/empty/create` service or by dragging and dropping from Fuel

To generate an SDFormat string, run:

```ign service -s /world/empty/generate_world_sdf --reqtype ignition.msgs.SdfGeneratorConfig --reptype ignition.msgs.StringMsg --timeout 3000 --req ' '
```
values.title: Add ability to save worlds to SDFormat

This PR adds a service for generating SDFormat strings/files for worlds. There are multiple options for generating the SDFormat. 

1. Expand and inline included models
2. Use the Fuel version in the URI generated for the model
3. Use absolute or relative paths for resources such as meshes

Of these options, only the first two are currently implemented in this PR.

- Only models in the ECM are generated. This means a world that uses levels won't be saved correctly
- The pose of models does not get updated properly if changes are made using the GUI transform tool while simulation is paused and the SDF generation service is called. It looks like the Pose component is not updated while simulation is paused. I think fixing that is beyond the scope of this PR.

Assumptions:

- In order to get the version number of Fuel URIs, I assume that the directory containing the model has a name that specifies the version.

summary.html:
This PR adds a service for generating SDFormat strings/files for worlds. There are multiple options for generating the SDFormat.

  1. Expand and inline included models
  2. Use the Fuel version in the URI generated for the model
  3. Use absolute or relative paths for resources such as meshes
  4. Copy model resources, such as meshes, and create a self contained model.

Of these options, only the first two are currently implemented in this PR.

Limitations:

  • Only models in the ECM are generated. This means a world that uses levels won't be saved correctly
  • The pose of models does not get updated properly if changes are made using the GUI transform tool while simulation is paused and the SDF generation service is called. It looks like the Pose component is not updated while simulation is paused. I think fixing that is beyond the scope of this PR.

Assumptions:

  • In order to get the version number of Fuel URIs, I assume that the directory containing the model has a name that specifies the version.

TODO:

  • Tie this into the GUI and save to file

Required:

  • ign-msgs PR #174

Try It

Run:

ign gazebo -v 4 -r empty.sdf

Insert models using the /world/empty/create service or by dragging and dropping from Fuel

To generate an SDFormat string, run:

ign service -s /world/empty/generate_world_sdf --reqtype ignition.msgs.SdfGeneratorConfig --reptype ignition.msgs.StringMsg --timeout 3000 --req ' '

values.description:
Depends on [ign-physics pull request #122](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-physics/pull-requests/122/add-get-bounding-box-features/diff)

* Added AxisAlignedBox component to store bounding box info

* Updated physics system to compute bounding box of model only if the AxisAlignedbox component exists.

‌
values.title: Add support for computing model bounding box in physics system

depends on sdformat [pull request #671](https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/671/add-transparency-to-visual-dom/diff)

Setting a <visual>'s <transparency> in sdf should now work.

Here’s an example of setting the visual transparency of a simple shape and a mesh:

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/508375828-visual_transparency.png)
‌

values.description:
I noticed these warnings from the entity tree: 

```[GUI] [Wrn] [Application.cc:649] [QT] file::/EntityTree/EntityTree.qml:242: ReferenceError: ma is not defined```

```[GUI] [Wrn] [Application.cc:649] [QT] file::/EntityTree/EntityTree.qml:247: TypeError: Cannot read property of null```

I'm not sure if deleting those lines is the correct thing to do, but I didn't notice any difference and the entity tree still operates the same.
values.title: Remove warning lines

values.description:
Add a `TrajectoryPose` component which allows setting a pose for the actor with respect to the actor's `component::Pose`. 

While `components::Pose` changes the origin of the trajectory, `TrajectoryPose` overrides `<script><trajectory>`. So on the demo you'll see that the actor starts walking in place.

In the future, I'd like to also use the `TrajectoryPose` to report the pose coming from the SDF trajectory. When that happens, we'll need a way to differentiate a pose that was set from the SDF calculations, from a pose that was set from a system. Not sure yet what's the best way to do that, but a couple options are:

* Add a `ScriptFromSdf` boolean component that indicates whether the SDF should be used or the component from other systems.
* Add a `TrajectoryPoseCmd` component that is meant to be used by other systems, while `RenderUtil` is the one populating the `TrajectoryPose` ground truth.
values.title: Actor trajectory pose

summary.raw:
Add a `TrajectoryPose` component which allows setting a pose for the actor with respect to the actor's `component::Pose`. 

While `components::Pose` changes the origin of the trajectory, `TrajectoryPose` overrides `<script><trajectory>`. So on the demo you'll see that the actor starts walking in place.

In the future, I'd like to also use the `TrajectoryPose` to report the pose coming from the SDF trajectory. When that happens, we'll need a way to differentiate a pose that was set from the SDF calculations, from a pose that was set from a system. Not sure yet what's the best way to do that, but a couple options are:

* Add a `ScriptFromSdf` boolean component that indicates whether the SDF should be used or the component from other systems.
* Add a `TrajectoryPoseCmd` component that is meant to be used by other systems, while `RenderUtil` is the one populating the `TrajectoryPose` ground truth.
summary.html:
Add a TrajectoryPose component which allows setting a pose for the actor with respect to the actor's component::Pose.

While components::Pose changes the origin of the trajectory, TrajectoryPose overrides <script><trajectory>. So on the demo you'll see that the actor starts walking in place.

In the future, I'd like to also use the TrajectoryPose to report the pose coming from the SDF trajectory. When that happens, we'll need a way to differentiate a pose that was set from the SDF calculations, from a pose that was set from a system. Not sure yet what's the best way to do that, but a couple options are:

  • Add a ScriptFromSdf boolean component that indicates whether the SDF should be used or the component from other systems.
  • Add a TrajectoryPoseCmd component that is meant to be used by other systems, while RenderUtil is the one populating the TrajectoryPose ground truth.

values.reason: Build on top of Ian's PR later
